course.post_content: For this module of the Virtual Expedition Training for DofE, Chief Scout’s Platinum, Chief Scout’s Diamond and King’s Scout Award we’re looking at the basics of the Expedition section and the expedition requirements.

_tutor_course_target_audience: All expedition participants should complete this module.

categories.name: Bronze
categories.description: Materials targeted at bronze award participants.

categories.name: Gold
categories.description: Materials targeted at gold award participants.

categories.name: Silver
categories.description: Materials targeted at silver award participants.

contents.post_content: This section will help you understand the expedition requirements

children.post_content:
Basic Requirements

All participants must be within the qualifying age of the programme level and at the same Award level (i.e., not have completed the same or higher level of expedition).

There must be between four and seven participants in a team (eight for modes of travel which can be used by two people at once e.g., tandem bikes, open canoes).

The expedition must be of the correct duration and meet the minimum hours of planned activity.

  • Bronze: A minimum of 2 days, 1 night; 6 hours of planned activity each day.
  • Silver: A minimum of 3 days, 2 nights; 7 hours of planned activity each day.
  • Gold: A minimum of 4 days, 3 nights; 8 hours of planned activity each day.

Participants must be adequately trained to safely complete an expedition in the environment in which they will be operating:

  • Bronze: Teams must complete the required training.
  • Silver: Teams must complete the required training and a practice expedition of a minimum 2 days, 2 nights.
  • Gold: Teams must complete the required training and a practice expedition of a minimum 2 days, 2 nights.

Your Expedition Must...

Team Goal

Expeditions must have a clearly defined team goal – this could be researching an area of interest, contributing to a community action project, or developing soft skills.

Environment

The environment chosen must become progressively more challenging through the award levels – environments could include rural, urban or restricted spaces.

Accommodation

Accommodation should be by camping or other simple self-catering accommodation e.g., bunkhouses.

Note SEEE expeditions are almost always campnig.

Time of year

Expeditions will usually take place between the end of March and the end of October. There should be a reasonable gap between the practice and qualifying expeditions.

Note: For SEEE expeditions the practices are usually in May/June and the qualifying expedition in August/September. You should already know the dates of both.

Mode of travel

Participants must choose an appropriate mode of travel for the environment they’ll be journeying through. Journeying must be by participants’ own physical effort, although mobility aids may be used where appropriate to the needs of the participant.

Note: In the case of expeditions with SEEE this will be biking, canoeing or hillwalking.

Food

Participants must plan an appropriate expedition menu, including cooking and eating a substantial hot meal each day (optional on the final day).

On Your Expedition

Participants must behave responsibly with respect for their team members, Leaders, landowners, the public and animals, and must understand and adhere to the Countryside, Scottish Outdoor Access, Highway and Water Sports Codes (as appropriate).

Expeditions must be unaccompanied and self-sufficient. The team must be properly equipped, and supervision must be carried out remotely, considering what is reasonably practicable for participants and ensuring their welfare is paramount.

Participants must actively participate in a debrief with their Assessor at the end of the expedition and, at Silver and Gold level, a presentation must be delivered after the expedition.

If, during your expedition, your conduct or performance don't meet the expedition requirements outlined above, your assessor will let you know and give you the opportunity to correct yourself.

contents.post_content: All teams must undertake a project while they are on their expedition. This section explains what you have to do.

children.post_content:
Every Qualifying Expedition must have a Team Goal, usually some sort of project involving all members of the group.  You should discuss this in your walking group – and pick something.  You should then do any research and preparation you need to.  A well chosen Goal can make your expedition much more fun!

Note, too, that every group at Silver and Gold has to prepare and deliver a Presentation about their expedition, which is usually linked to the Team Goal, so it is worth choosing something interesting, and agreeing how you can make sure you will have the photos etc for the presentation.

The presentation is best done a couple of weeks or so after the expedition, while it is fresh in your mind.

A good expedition aim should:

  • Give a purpose to your expedition
  • Suitable for the environment
  • Be carried out whatever the weather
  • Can be presented back easily
  • Involve all members at some point
  • Be enjoyable to research
  • Compatible with self-sufficient expedition
  • Be expressed in a single sentence
  • Involve the whole group doing something

Here are some goals that other people have done, to give you some ideas. The columns B/S/G indicate whether the idea was done as for bronze, silver and gold. There is also another set of ideas from the DofE on the exercise files tab.

Topic for GoalTopic areaBSG
Land useGeographyBSG
Weather observationsGeographyBSG
Impact of tourismGeographyBSG
FarmingGeographyBSG
LandformsGeology/Geography SG
Glaciation featuresGeology/Geography SG
Find and record interesting rocksGeology/ActivityB  
WildlifeNature/BiologyBSG
TreesNature/BiologyBSG
PlantsNature/BiologyBSG
Pollution levelsNature/Biology SG
Energy input/outputBiology  G
Group dynamicsGroup SG
M/F dynamics within groupGroup  G
Learn about each otherGroupBSG
Effect of being off-gridGroup  G
Learn a skill from one member (eg a language)Group  G
Supporting member(s) with additional needsGroupBSG
Record detailed timings for legs of route, with observationsGroupBS 
Take photos at agreed points and make observations based on a topic: land, nature, weather …ResearchBSG
Video of ExpeditionMediaBSG
Photo recordMediaBSG
Diary/blogMedia/PersonalBSG
Poetry/song recordMedia/PersonalBSG
Sketches recordMedia SG
Multimedia recordMediaBSG
History of areaHistoryBSG
Compare historic mapsHistory/Geography SG
Place names (Gaelic etc)History/Geography SG
Religious/supernatural linksHistoryBSG
GeocachingActivityBSG
Alphabet observationActivityB  
Litter – mapping, collectingActivityB  
Map erosion on tracksActivityB  
Take photos of group at different points and map location of photosActivity/MediaB  
Taking selfies as a group at main waypoints to create a collage of our expedition journeyActivity/MediaB  
Researching named features, notices, plaques … Perhaps part of a topic.ActivityBS

contents.post_content: This section explains our policy with respect to mobile phones and other electronic devices while on your expedition.

children.post_content:
Electronics and mobile phone policy

One of the expedition requirements is self-sufficiency. During the expedition, your focus should be your team and the expedition itself - that is a key part of the expedition experience. Unless there's a valid reason, your phone should be off and in your bag.

  • Mobile phones should only be used for emergency purposes i.e. contacting your
    supervisor/assessor in the event of an accident/incident you need to discuss with them which will alter your route or if you are running very late (e.g. 2 hours). They should be turned off in a sealed bag ideally with the first aid kit.
  • Phoning or messaging your parents / boyfriend / girlfriend, catching up on the football scores and so on are not generally good reasons to get your phone out.
  • If you need to take photos or videos for your project, consider getting a single purpose device
  • This is the suggested policy. If you have particular needs, you should discuss with your supervisor and assessor at the beginning of the expedition and ensure your phone is turned off when not required to preserve battery.

You should register your phone with the 999 service (see www.emergencysms.org.uk). 

You should also download the OS Explore app, which will give you an accurate grid reference in an emergency.

children.post_title: Expedition requirements and team goal quiz

question.question_title: Which of the following are NOT consistent with the expedition requirements?

answers.answer_title: You have a team of 8 people
You cook a hot meal with your team mates each night
You stop at a shop to stock up on supplies
You hike each day and your route card includes time to work on your team goal
You discard your food waste to lighten your load. It\'ll rot away, after all.
You are running late, so you accept a lift from a helpful farmer to help get back on track.

question.question_title: It\'s OK to send updates to your boyfriend / girlfriend so long as it\'s no more than three times a day
Which of the following is a good team goal

answers.answer_title: To complete the 15km route each day before 4:00 PM so the team can rest.
To allow the Team Leader to practice their navigation skills while the rest of the group focuses on morale.
To study and record the variety of wildflowers found at different altitudes along our route for a post-expedition presentation.
To ensure that every team member survives the trip without losing any personal gear.
